reasoning: 1. Circle of Competence: Amazon falls outside my wheelhouse. I don’t pretend to understand the ever-changing logistics, cloud computing and razor-thin retail economics the way I do a soft drink or an insurance franchise. As I’ve said, “Risk comes from not knowing what you’re doing,” and I don’t know how to forecast the next turn in a business that burns capital, issues stock, and shifts strategy every few years.  2. Moat: While Amazon has scale and Prime switching costs, its return on equity is a meager 2.1% and barely positive owner earnings. A durable moat should show up in consistent 15%-plus ROEs—Amazon delivers nothing of the sort.  3. Management & Capital Allocation: They’re talented folks running a sprawling empire, but they’ve issued new stock recently, diluting shareholders, and paid no dividends. I prefer managers who think like owners and return cash when the business doesn’t have higher-return reinvestment opportunities.  4. Financial Health & Consistency: ROIC sits near zero, debt-to-equity exceeds 2×, owner earnings are negative and growth has been erratic (-45% over 10 periods). A true financial fortress doesn’t post red ink in its DCF or swing from boom to bust.  5. Valuation: The three-stage DCF spits out a negative intrinsic value of roughly $-236,000 per share equivalent, and the margin of safety is glaringly negative. You can’t buy a store for less than nothing.  6. Long-Term Prospects & Red Flags: Sure, they’ll grow sales, but returns on capital remain too low and the business eats cash. I see no catalyst for dramatic margin expansion. In retail and cloud, competition from Walmart, Microsoft, Alibaba and others looms large.  7. Better Opportunities: I’d rather own a great business like Coca-Cola at a fair price, or Apple for its consumer ecosystem and cash returns, than gamble on capital-intensive ventures with modest profits. In short, I’ll pass on Amazon.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 2.1%; High debt to equity ratio of 2.1; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of -45.2% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 0/10 periods >15%; Strong and stable operating margins (avg: 49.2%) indicate pricing power moat

book_value_analysis.details: Good book value per share growth pattern

management_analysis.details: Recent common stock issuance (potential dilution); No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (-1.6%, 5y), Stage 2 (-0.8%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
